# Overlapping frequency polygons {#sec-overlapping-frequency-polygons} ::: {.callout-tip appearance='simple' icon=false} ***This graph is largely complete and just needs final proof reading.*** ::: :::: {.callout-note collapse="false" icon=false}
::: {.cell layout-align="right"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](overlapping_frequency_polygons_files/figure-html/full_code_display-1.png){fig-align='right' width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #02577A;"} **This graph requires:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.05em; color: #282b2d;"} **✅ a categorical variable** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.05em; color: #282b2d;"} **✅ a numeric (continuous) variable** ::: :::: ## Description Overlapping frequency polygons are similar to overlapping histograms--they allow us to compare distributions of a continuous variable across the levels of a categorical variable. Instead of using bars, frequency polygons use lines to show the shape of the distribution. ## Set up ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **PACKAGES:** ::: Install packages. ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(palmerpenguins) library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **DATA:** ::: ::: {.column-margin} ![Artwork by allison horst](www/lter_penguins.png){fig-align="right" width="100%" height="100%"} ::: The `penguins` data. ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} penguins <- palmerpenguins::penguins glimpse(penguins) #> Rows: 344 #> Columns: 8 #> $ species Adelie, Adelie, Adelie… #> $ island Torgersen, Torgersen, … #> $ bill_length_mm 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, … #> $ bill_depth_mm 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, … #> $ flipper_length_mm 181, 186, 195, NA, 193… #> $ body_mass_g 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, … #> $ sex male, female, female, … #> $ year 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007… ``` ::: ::: :::: ## Grammar ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **CODE:** ::: - Create labels with `labs()` - Initialize the graph with `ggplot()` and provide `data` - Map `flipper_length_mm` to the `x` and `species` to `group` - Map `species` to the `color` aesthetic *inside* the `geom_freqpoly()` ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} labs_ovrlp_freq_poly <- labs( title = "Adult foraging penguins", x = "Flipper length (mm)", color = "Species") ggp2_ovrlp_freq_poly <- ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, group = species)) + geom_freqpoly(aes(color = species)) ggp2_ovrlp_freq_poly + labs_ovrlp_freq_poly ``` ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **GRAPH:** ::: ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](overlapping_frequency_polygons_files/figure-html/create_graph_freq_poly-1.png){width=100% height=100%} ::: :::
